title.narrative: Land subsidence and groundwater use in the Mekong Delta – towards behavioural change

description.narrative: The Mekong Delta is critically important for Viet Nam’s agriculture and aquaculture production and export. However, floods, droughts, saline water intrusion, and water pollution strongly affect this. These risks are enhanced by global climate change and sea level rise, as well as upstream dam construction and other development. Land subsidence is caused in particular by over-exploitation of groundwater and has become a major additional threat as it worsens e.g. flood risks. Land subsidence is a growing problem, with cumulative total subsidence in some places of more than 30 cm over the past 25 years. Annual rates are currently exceeding sea level rise by a factor 5 to 10 in coastal zones and the middle delta, reaching 3 cm per year in some parts; and the very latest INSAR data analysis suggests that in some cities and shrimp farming areas the rates are already 5-6 cm per year. The primary cause is depletion of groundwater from deep aquifers with very low natural recharge rates. Multiple lines of research show that groundwater exploitation is indeed the dominant driver of land subsidence, but other drivers of land subsidence are natural settlement; subsurface drainage that accelerates settlement of upper soil layers; tectonic movement and isostasy; the surface load, i.e. weight of buildings and infrastructure. In addition, the sediment flux, which in the natural situation more than compensated natural settlement as the Mekong Delta was growing in size, is reducing as a result of human interventions.The Netherlands has experienced land subsidence for centuries and is one of the global experts. It wants to share its expertise with Viet Nam and especially the Mekong Delta, in addition to expertise on water safety and climate change adaptation. This must build on past, current, and planned Dutch supported initiatives. It also wants to create business opportunities for Dutch technologies and services. The Rise & Fall research program between Utrecht University and Can Tho University has been instrumental in generating knowledge and raising awareness of land subsidence and groundwater exploitation. This assignment resulted in several follow-up activities related to the topic of land subsidence and groundwater use in the Mekong Delta.This project is conducted in cooperation with: Climate Sense, Deltares and Utrecht University.
